facts.text: Gudar Dusadh is the appellant.

facts.text: Gudar Dusadh was tried along with 23 others in the court of Additional Sessions Judge Saran.

anchor.surface_text: Gudar Dusadh appellant was tried along with 23 others in the court of Additional Sessions Judge Saran. Eighteen of the accused were acquitted by the trial court.

facts.text: Eighteen accused were acquitted by the trial court.

anchor.surface_text: Eighteen of the accused were acquitted by the trial court. The appellant was convicted under sections 302 and 147 Indian Penal Code

facts.text: Appellant was convicted under sections 302 and 147 IPC and sentenced to life imprisonment for 302.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant was convicted under sections 302 and 147 Indian Penal Code and was sentenced to undergo imprisonment for life on the former count. No separate sentence was awarded

facts.text: Five accused were convicted under section 323 read with 149 IPC and minor offences.

anchor.surface_text: No separate sentence was awarded to the appellant for the offence under section 147 Indian Penal Code. The remaining five accused were convicted under section 323 read with section 149

facts.text: Patna High Court maintained conviction and sentence of appellant.

anchor.surface_text: On appeal the Patna High Court maintained the conviction and sentence of the appellant, while some modification was made as regards the sentence

facts.text: Appeal to Supreme Court by special leave, confined to whether offence was murder or culpable homicide not amounting to murder.

facts.text: Occurrence took place in village Khahla, district Saran at about 11 a.m. on August 14, 1965.

anchor.surface_text: The case relates to an occurrence which took place in village Khahla in district Saran at about 11 a.m. on August 14, 1965. Ramlal Bhagat, who was aged about 65 years,

facts.text: Ramlal Bhagat aged about 65 years died as a result of assault.

anchor.surface_text: Ramlal Bhagat, who was aged about 65 years, died as a result of the assault during the course of the occurrence while his son Ramashish Prasad PW 10 received injuries.

facts.text: Ramashish Prasad PW 10 received injuries.

anchor.surface_text: died as a result of the assault during the course of the occurrence while his son Ramashish Prasad PW 10 received injuries. The case of the prosecution is that a day

facts.text: Day before occurrence, Prasadi Dusadh and Ganesh Dusadh killed goat of Baharan Bhagat PW 8.

anchor.surface_text: The case of the prosecution is that a day before the occurrence Prasadi Dusadh and Ganesh Dusadh killed a goat belonging to Baharan Bhagat PW 8 . On the advice

facts.text: Baharan Bhagat lodged report with police at 3 p.m. on advice of Ramlal Bhagat.

anchor.surface_text: On the advice of Ramlal Bhagat deceased, Baharan Bhagat lodged a report with the police at 3 p.m. on that day. On the morning of August 14, 1965 Ramlal

facts.text: Ramlal and Ramashish went to paddy field morning of August 14, 1965, returning at 11 a.m. assaulted by six convicted persons hiding on route.

anchor.surface_text: On the morning of August 14, 1965 Ramlal and his son Ramashish went to their paddy field. While they were returning from the field at about 11 a.m. they were assaulted

facts.text: Appellant gave lathi blow on head of Ramlal, who fell down and died at spot.

anchor.surface_text: by the six convicted persons who had been hiding on the route. The appellant gave a lathi blow on the head of Ramlal as a result of which the latter fell down

facts.text: Companion of appellant shouted assault due to Ramlal responsible for criminal proceedings by Baharan.

anchor.surface_text: and died at the spot. One of the companions of the appellant then shouted that the assault was made because of Ramlal being-responsible for the commencement of criminal

facts.text: Injuries caused to Ramashish.

anchor.surface_text: Some injuries were also caused to Ramashish. The accused then set fire to one of their huts

facts.text: Accused set fire to one of their huts to prepare defence, then fled.

anchor.surface_text: The accused then set fire to one of their huts with a view to prepare some kind of defence. After that the accused fled away,

facts.text: SHO Sarju Prasad Singh received info of large number from accused party collecting to attack despite section 144 order, came to place after Ramlal killed.

anchor.surface_text: SHO Sarju Prasad Singh of police station Barauli on receipt of information that a large number of persons belonging to the party of the accused had collected to attack

facts.text: SHO recorded statement of Ramashish, formal FIR prepared.

anchor.surface_text: Sarju Prasad Singh recorded the statement of Ramashish and on the basis of that statement, a formal information report was prepared at the police station.

facts.text: Post mortem on Ramlal by Dr. R. S. Singh on August 15, 1965.

anchor.surface_text: Post mortem examination on the body of Ramlal deceased was performed by Dr. R. S. Singh on August 15, 1965.

facts.text: Appellant pleaded falsely involved by village Mukhia who was inimical.

facts.text: Lacerated wound 2" x 1/2" bone deep on left side of head, ante-mortem, caused by lathi-like weapon.

facts.text: 3" long fracture of left parietal bone.

facts.text: Large amount of blood and clots on left side of brain, death due to compression on left side of brain.

facts.text: Injury sufficient in ordinary course to cause death.

anchor.surface_text: The doctor further stated that the above injury was sufficient in the ordinary course of nature to cause death.

facts.text: Appellant and companions lying in wait to attack Ramlal.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant along with his companions was lying in wait to attack Ramlal and, according to the evidence on record which has been accepted

facts.text: No altercation or exchange of abuses between Ramlal and accused party.

anchor.surface_text: It has also been found by the High Court that there was no altercation or exchange of abuses between Ramlal and the accused party.

facts.text: Assault premeditated, blow on head not accidental.

anchor.surface_text: The circumstances of the case thus show that the assault was premeditated and the blow on the head of Ramlal was not accidental.

facts.text: Appellant gave only one blow on head.

facts.text: Ramlal died instantaneously.

anchor.surface_text: Ramlal deceased died instantaneously and as such, there arose no occasion for giving a second blow to him.

issues.text: whether there was an intention on the part of the accused to inflict the particular injury which was found on the body of the deceased

anchor.surface_text: Under the first part, it has to be shown that there was an intention on the part of the accused to inflict the particular injury which was found on the body of the deceased. The second part requires that the bodily injury intended to be inflicted was sufficient in the ordinary course of nature to cause death.

issues.text: whether the bodily injury intended to be inflicted was sufficient in the ordinary course of nature to cause death

anchor.surface_text: The second part requires that the bodily injury intended to be inflicted was sufficient in the ordinary course of nature to cause death. So far as the first part is concerned, the court has to see whether the injury which was found on the deceased was the one intended by the accused or whether it was accidental without his having intended to cause that bodily injury.

arguments.claim: Clause 3rdly consists of two parts: (1) intention to inflict particular injury; (2) injury sufficient to cause death

anchor.surface_text: According to that clause, culpable homicide is murder if it is done with the intention of causing bodily injury to any person and the bodily injury intended to be inflicted is sufficient in the ordinary course of nature to cause death. Clause 3rdly consists of two parts.

holdings.text: The case against the appellant would fall squarely within the ambit of clause 3rdly of section 300 Indian Penal Code.

anchor.surface_text: As the injury on the head was deliberate and not accidental and as the injury was sufficient in the ordinary course of nature to cause death, the case against the appellant would fall squarely within the ambit of clause 3rdly of section 300 Indian Penal Code.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Assault premeditated, blow on head deliberate, injury sufficient per doctor; satisfies both parts of clause 3rdly.

holdings.text: In the present case, both parts of the clause 3rdly have been satisfied.

holdings.text: There was an intention on the part of the accused to inflict the particular injury which was found on the body of the deceased.

anchor.surface_text: Clause 3rdly consists of two parts. Under the first part, it has to be shown that there was an intention on the part of the accused to inflict the particular injury which was found on the body of the deceased.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No evidence of accidental blow or supervening cause; blow aimed at head, lying in wait indicates intent.

holdings.text: The bodily injury intended to be inflicted was sufficient in the ordinary course of nature to cause death.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Doctor's opinion: lacerated wound bone-deep with fracture and brain compression sufficient to cause death.

holdings.text: The fact that the appellant gave only one blow on the head would not mitigate the offence of the appellant and make him guilty of the offence of culpable homicide not amounting to murder.

anchor.surface_text: The circumstances of the case thus show that the assault was premeditated and the blow on the head of Ramlal was not accidental. The fact that the appellant gave only one blow on the head would not mitigate the offence of the appellant

holdings.reasoning_summary: Death instantaneous, no need for second blow; single deliberate blow sufficient for murder.

holdings.text: The above case does not warrant the proposition that if the accused gives a deliberate blow on the head of the deceased with a lathi and thereby causes an injury as is sufficient in the ordinary course of nature to cause death and actually results in death, the case against him would not fall under clause 3rdly of section 300 of Indian Penal Code.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Chamru Budhwa distinguished: no sudden fight or exchange of abuses here; premeditated assault unlike there.

anchor.surface_text: As the injury on the head was deliberate and not accidental and as the injury was sufficient in the ordinary course of nature to cause death, the case against the appellant would fall squarely within the ambit of clause 3rdly of section 300 Indian Penal Code.
The appellant who caused the above injury to Ramlal deceased, in our opinion, was guilty of the offence of murder and he has been rightly companyvicted under section 302

anchor.surface_text: Clause 3rdly consists of two parts. Under the first part, it has to be shown that there was an intention on the part of the accused to inflict the particular injury which was found on the body of the deceased.

anchor.surface_text: The second part requires that the bodily injury intended to be inflicted was sufficient in the ordinary course of nature to cause death.
